newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Striking Venezuela doctors return to work.
newsitem.headline: Striking Venezuela doctors return to work.

text.p: Striking Venezuelan doctors said on Tuesday they would return to work in emergency wards and resume stalled pay talks with the government after walking out of hospitals last Friday.
"Depending on how the talks go will determine how long the truce lasts," Federation of Venezuelan Medics president Fernando Bianco told Reuters.
The Venezuelan government has blamed the striking doctors for six deaths during the strike.
But representatives of Venezuela's 27,000 public doctors, who have asked for a 1,000-percent pay rise, said the government was to blame.
Venezuelan doctors earn an average $126 per month in a public health system notoriously underfunded and poorly supplied.
Over the weekend unattended mothers gave birth in hospital doorways and patients went untreated as overstretched military doctors staffed emergency wards throughout the country.
Doctors had ignored a presidential decree that ordered them back to work on Friday.

"They have taken the Venezuelan poor hostage and are simply decreeing death sentences to those that arrive at emergency wards in a serious condition," Planning Minister Teodoro Petkoff said before the doctors agreed to return to work.
"The expectation of a $1,000 minimum salary, however just it might be, is just outside the reach of the Venezuelan economy," he added.
